movie: All the Money in the World
review: Mr. Plummer, who replaced Kevin Spacey in the role of J. Paul Getty, is magnetic in the film, which recounts the 1973 kidnapping of his grandson.
In Fatih Akin's new film, Diane Kruger plays a Hamburg woman who fights for justice and sanity after the murder of her husband and son.
Paul Thomas Anderson's latest film is a luxuriant love story set in 1950s London.
Did Goebbels's secretary do anything more than type? This documentary lets viewers judge.

movie: Along With the Gods: The Two Worlds
review: This delirious fantasy from Kim Yong-hwa, adapted from a web comic, buries story clarity and emotional depth under a mountain of visual pyrotechnics.
David Ayer's urban action film is a loud, ungainly hybrid that does not serve police procedurals or fantasy spectaculars very well.
Alexander Payne looks at the big picture in his new movie.
This film about two brothers searching for their real father can't decide whether it's a gross-out comedy or an uplifting tale of brotherly love.
Isabelle Huppert, Toby Jones and Mathieu Kassovitz make up a remarkable ensemble cast. But “Happy End” belongs to Jean-Louis Trintignant.
The magical game is back, and this time it's turning geeks into action heroes and jocks into zoologists.
The latest entry in this movie series fares best when its director treats it as a fantastical buddy comedy.
The film has the ingredients of a splashy good time — the charismatic Hugh Jackman, for one — but it fast becomes a standard-issue holiday biopic.
Liam O'Donnell's genre-hopping film takes its characters from Los Angeles to Laos, but risks losing its audience along the way.
The movie has talking animals, but it's not necessarily for kids.
This psycho-in-the-woods tale benefits from sensitive writing and organic performances.
Ferdinand, the picture-book bull that is actually quite tame, gets new life in a computer-animated adaptation from Carlos Saldanha.
The true-crime documentary lays out a persuasive case for reasonable doubt in the case against Jens Soering, who was convicted, along with his girlfriend.
The documentary by Petra Lataster-Czisch and Peter Lataster follows young students in the classroom but doesn't examine their lives outside school.
Rainn Wilson and Patricia Arquette play the parents of a girl who gets the titular treatment in this unsuccessful comedy.
This documentary from Thomas Morgan, about a female entrepreneur establishing a business just south of Beirut, is a stirring tale of empowerment.
With charm and wit, the latest “Star Wars” movie unites the past and present as it looks toward the future.
In this droll comedy from Pavan Moondi, a pair of feckless layabouts are assigned to video-record a wedding at a Mexican resort. Mishaps ensue.
Bill Pullman stars in this Montana-set western, which tips its cowboy hat to classics of the genre.
Nancy Buirski's film is one of multiple layers and marvelous gumption.
The director Emma Franz focuses on a musician who seems to never stop playing, featuring great collaborators of this “no drama” artist.
When the brother of Dianna Agron's character is accused of murder, it's up to her to save him and their family reputation.
In this winking biopic, Margot Robbie plays the disgraced ice skater Tonya Harding.
The writer-director Ron Shelton returns to his favorite themes in this comedy starring Morgan Freeman, Tommy Lee Jones and Rene Russo.
A toxic mother-son bond drives Rupert Jones's glum British psychodrama.
This documentary from Jonathan Olshefski follows a North Philadelphia family through the Obama years.
James Franco directs and stars in this fictionalized look at the making of “The Room,” which fans call the worst movie ever made.
Hope Litoff's documentary becomes more voyeuristically gripping as it progresses.
The rap luminary RZA and the hip-hop musician Azealia Banks team up for a story of rap and poetry, “Love Beats Rhymes.”
Taken from a British intelligence officer's memoir, and narrated by Benedict Cumberbatch, this film paints a portrait of the occupied city.
An alcoholic cop and her pregnant daughter are forced to reckon with their mistakes in this Peruvian drama.
Richard Hambleton, a peer of Jean-Michel Basquiat and Keith Haring who went underground, was painting right up until his death this fall.
A drama about a prison escapee in hiding plays out against the backdrop of the 2011 demonstrations in Cairo's Tahrir Square.
The film, directed by Stéphanie Di Giusto, seems genuinely hostile to its subject, the dancer Loïe Fuller, whose real-life accomplishments deserve better.
The documentary follows Cody Wilson, who published plans to create a gun using a 3-D printer.
Not even a move to a picture-perfect California paradise can buoy a troubled family.
This squirmy documentary follows the celebrated journalist Gay Talese's infamous investigation of a motel owner who spied on guests.
Kate Winslet plays an unhappily married woman whose affair with a local Romeo is derailed when he falls for her stepdaughter.
In this film, Turin's poorest tell their stories to the camera.
In the latest movie from the Italian director Luca Guadagnino (“I Am Love”), Armie Hammer plays a visiting student who falls for his host's teenage son.
The movie delivers moments of cinematic rigor and playful pop-culture erudition. And though it deals with the afterlife, don't let that scare you.
Glenn Close, Julian Sands, Gillian Anderson and Christina Hendricks make up an all-star roster of suspects in this Agatha Christie adaptation.
The filmmaker Jon Alpert has been visiting and documenting Cuba for 45 years. His new movie looks back fondly at its people and its leader.
Gary Oldman plays Winston Churchill in Joe Wright's drama about the early days of World War II.
A documentary on the life of Eric Clapton is candid on the rock legend's struggles with addiction.
The detectives in this serial-killer thriller can't even be bothered to solve the word puzzle.
Noël Wells wrote, directed and stars in this film about a young woman who returns to her former home and discovers much has changed.
Dan Gilroy's new film about a socially awkward jurist misfires when it appoints him as a sort of angelic figure.
This drama purports that Charles Dickens took inspiration for his fictional characters from real-life encounters.
This mockumentary about a cooking competition features Melissa McCarthy but is being released 10 years after it was first shown at a comedy festival.

movie: Jim & Andy: The Great Beyond - Featuring a Very Special, Contractually Obligated Mention of Tony Clifton
review: In his documentary about Jim Carrey, Andy Kaufman and the making of “Man on the Moon,” the director Chris Smith finds multiple realities and laughs.
In this superhero jamboree, the Flash, Aquaman and Cyborg sign on with the DC Comics team leaders Batman and Wonder Woman. (Psst … where's Superman?)
Dee Rees's new film illuminates the daily cruelties in post-World War II Mississippi.
This biography of the singer Joe Heaney seems uncertain of what made him tick.
The children in this animated film based on a novel by Deborah Ellis navigate life under the Taliban.
Let's make no bones about it: This film, part of a project to reboot a Japanese soft-core genre, is designed to appeal to male prurient interest.
Auggie, the little boy in this smart and warmhearted family film, is inspirational in his differences.
Jason Ritter plays a husband whose wife goes to the dogs in this feminist horror-comedy.
Mel Gibson gets off lightly as a crass paterfamilias in this comedy sequel to the hit starring Will Ferrell and Mark Wahlberg.
This film from Tom Gustafson, based on a 1993 Off Broadway show, has a formidable cast of Broadway names but wants for dramatic traction.
The director Oskar Thor Axelsson prefers mood and compelling human conflict over copious gore to deliver chills. The result is effective.
This documentary, directed by Joe Berlinger, explores the Armenian genocide through old footage of survivors and insights from historians.
“Mayhem,” featuring the “Walking Dead” actor Steven Yeun, embraces its pulpy title with fighting-and-fornicating glee.
Kenneth Branagh assembles Judi Dench, Johnny Depp, Michelle Pfeiffer and others for his film remake of Agatha Christie's mystery novel.
A ferocious Frances McDormand plays a grieving mother seeking justice in Martin McDonagh's movie, which mixes tears and tragedy with corrosive laughs.

movie: Window Horses: The Poetic Persian Epiphany of Rosie Ming
review: Ann Marie Fleming's film explores the passions of a sheltered poet who travels to Shiraz, Iran, for a poetry festival.
The documentary followed more than 16 people to the polls on Election Day to learn about their thoughts and feelings on the candidates.
Ferenc Torok's lean feature is a Holocaust film built, consciously or not, on a reversal of the tropes of the western.
Christine Baranski, Cheryl Hines and Susan Sarandon join the cast for a sequel to “Bad Moms.”
Erik Nelson's documentary centers on the aspiring filmmaker David Crowley, whose violent death became a cause for conspiracy theorists.
Dennis Hopper's life could be seen as a wild ride, on and off the screen. Someone who was by Hopper's side interprets his story.
A brokenhearted girl and an undying samurai team up in Takashi Miike's film.
The real Frank Serpico proves to be a compelling figure in a documentary that picks up where the classic Hollywood film left off.
This ensemble comedy from Michelle Morgan concerns one woman who exits a relationship, and another who seeks one. Their city only complicates matters.
Saoirse Ronan plays a high school senior who insists on asserting her individuality, and it makes for a thrilling film.
Three Vietnam vets — played by Steve Carell, Bryan Cranston and Laurence Fishburne — reunite during the Iraq war to accomplish a grim mission.
Woody Harrelson swaggers through this movie, which tries to track the coming into consciousness of Lyndon B. Johnson.
This suspense film, about a woman entering a rabbit hole of urban peril, is an effective writing-directing debut for Ana Asensio, who also stars.
The story of the making of a monster.
Cristina Herrera Borquez's documentary follows Victor Aguirre and Fernando Urias in their bureaucratic battle to be legally married.
Stephanie Beatriz plays a young woman who learns to survive after a night out ends in a brutal attack in this drama from Jessica M. Thompson.
In the newest, loosest, goofiest and funniest Thor blowout, Chris Hemsworth's superhero chillaxes with the Hulk and takes a punch from a Valkyrie.
These documentaries go behind the scenes with their well-known subjects, Rose Marie and Gilbert Gottfried.
This psychodrama from Marc Forster stars Blake Lively and Jason Clarke as a seemingly happy married couple.
This feature debut of the writer and director Francis Lee is a bracing, sometimes brutal movie.

movie: Joan Didion: The Center Will Not Hold
review: This documentary is directed by Griffin Dunne, Ms. Didion's nephew, a relationship that limits the movie in certain ways, but opens it up in others.
A character who wants to play with power in a movie that reeks of scholarly pretension.
A documentary looks at Charles Mully, who gave up great wealth to aid the poor and homeless in his country.
George Clooney stays off camera to direct Matt Damon and Julianne Moore in a caustic comedy about the good old American days of fear, hate and rage.
The film, from the screenwriter of “American Sniper,” is an earnest and powerful drama about Iraq veterans returning to Kansas.
Set in 1971, Petra Volpe's film takes a middlebrow, mildly rollicking approach toward a serious subject.
This documentary follows Izak Szewelewicz, who was sent to Israel as a toddler after World War II, on a search for the brother he didn't know he had.
This documentary focuses on the hyperkinetic card magician Richard Turner.
In this action film, the world is threatened by a space-based weather-control system armed with ice, fire, hail and heavy rain.
Daniel Radcliffe suffers for his art in this true-life survival tale about the Israeli adventurer Yossi Ghinsberg.
A film that opened in Paris in 1979 finally surfaces in the United States.
This film, which features Sam Shepard in his final, all-too-brief screen role, plays more like an experimental art project.
This documentary, directed by Heidi Ewing and Rachel Grady, follows three ultra-Orthodox Jews who have left the Hasidic community.
This action drama from Joseph Kosinski — about the Granite Mountain Hotshots of Prescott, Ariz. — offers some real feeling under a schematic surface.
Michael Fassbender and other talented people wander through this leaden mess.
In this slasher comedy, two high school social media stars find that murder is the best way to drum up followers for their online horror brand.

movie: Tyler Perry's Boo 2! A Madea Halloween
review: In this sequel that feels like a remake, all prospects for amusement are never even vaguely realized.
Mr. Haynes's lovely adaptation of Brian Selznick's book centers on a girl in the 1920s and a boy in the '70s whose lives are mysteriously connected.
A documentary by Alexandre O. Philippe finds plenty to examine in one of the most memorable scenes in American film.
The disability-rights pioneer Robin Cavendish is given an upbeat biopic in “Breathe,” starring Andrew Garfield and Claire Foy.
A documentary observes a St. Louis student facing a bleak future if she can't graduate from an alternative school.
A mean coed relives her own murder multiple times in this snappy horror-comedy.
Reginald Hudlin's movie about the crusading lawyer and Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall smartly keeps the focus tight.

movie: Professor Marston and the Wonder Women
review: In “Professor Marston and the Wonder Women,” the writer-director Angela Robinson tells a knotty story with wit, sympathy and economy.
A biopic about the rise of a Native American performer who overcame discriminatory laws to perform on Broadway and in the White House.
This documentary follows a Buddhist priest who counsels those who are in danger of committing suicide.
He plays an aggrieved father facing off against Pierce Brosnan, who plays a character with possible links to the I.R.A.
A career high, and not just for this film's writer and director, Noah Baumbach.
The mess that two Brooklyn brothers make of their house in this documentary is unholy in several senses of the term.
This feel-good documentary dives into global health care with the same optimism as its subjects, two founders of Partners in Health.
The director Denis Villeneuve tries to both honor Ridley Scott's 1982 dystopian classic and to slip free of its considerable shadow.
Mr. Vaughn plays a reluctant avenger in this vicious thriller from the director of “Bone Tomahawk.”
The documentary about the singer Chavela Vargas provides a biography, but doesn't give a strong sense of the musician's power.
An intimate, affecting film about a couple with autism, as they plan their wedding.
Scott Eastwood and Freddie Thorp star as brothers and car thieves in this action film.

movie: The Death and Life of Marsha P. Johnson
review: The documentary, by David France, looks at the death of the transgender activist. Police say it was suicide; friends suspect it was murder.
Idris Elba and Kate Winslet crash into a mountain — and each other — in this drama.
The film follows a father and son who trek into the Montana wilderness, only to encounter danger.
Mr. Cruise plays a real-life pilot turned smuggler who worked for the C.I.A., in Doug Liman's new movie.
A former Marine returns home and battles with post-traumatic stress in this film.
Ben Reade and Josh Evans travel the world to visit cultures where insects are prepared as food.
A slacker, his lover and his lover's husband make a sticky love triangle in this awkward comedy.
The original starred Julia Roberts, Kiefer Sutherland and Kevin Bacon, among others. The new one has Ellen Page and some horror movie tricks.
In one of his last roles, Harry Dean Stanton shines as a cantankerous old man.

movie: Mark Felt: The Man Who Brought Down the White House
review: Peter Landesman's accidentally timely Watergate procedural has men in suits fighting for the independence of the F.B.I.
This small-town romance was adapted from the novel by Kent Haruf.
Blending concert film and sports diary, Danny Clinch chronicles Pearl Jam's pair of shows at Wrigley Field during the Cubs' championship season.
This above-average science-fiction film, written and directed by Mateo Gil, plays like a “Black Mirror” episode combined with a solemn love story.
Kevin Phillips's direction and fine acting from the cast elevate this tale centered on two high schoolers coping with tragedy.

movie: Take Every Wave: The Life of Laird Hamilton
review: This documentary about Laird Hamilton, conqueror of big waves, stirs up most of its sporadic excitement with its surfing footage.
Emma Stone plays Billie Jean King and Steve Carell plays Bobby Riggs in a movie about the 1973 tennis match that became a referendum on equality.
This documentary depicts Lady Gaga as a disciplined, accomplished performer, but one who inhabits a peculiar isolation despite her fame.
This espionage sequel is an emotionally sterile lark, its wounds inflicted with a smirk and a shrug, even if it's Sir Elton John in the cross hairs.
An innovative biopic explores the Dutch painter's last days, with the people he rendered on canvas being brought to uncanny life.
With raw emotion, David Gordon Green's “Stronger” tells the true tale of Jeff Bauman, catastrophically injured as he watched the 2013 marathon.
A father, a son and the battle to save a snapped-together city.
It's 1979 and one aspiring engineer is ready for America and to win over his childhood sweetheart.
In this film, Jennifer Brea describes her life that Chronic Fatigue Syndrome hijacked.
“Victoria and Abdul” sees a queen in a life-changing relationship with a Muslim Indian man.
Kirsten Dunst stars in the hallucinatory first feature from the founders of Rodarte, Kate and Laura Mulleavy.
Ben Barenholtz kick-started the career of David Lynch. But his first fiction feature shows he has not mastered directing.
“American Assassin,” the first adaptation of a series of thrillers, stars Dylan O'Brien as a rogue C.I.A. killer and Michael Keaton as grizzled mentor.
Mike White's empty-nest comedy starring Ben Stiller is both cringy and kindhearted.

movie: First They Killed My Father: A Daughter of Cambodia Remembers
review: “First They Killed My Father” depicts life under the Khmer Rouge in a film taken from Loung Ung's memoir.
A sheltered young woman enamored of the films of the famous director sets off to Italy to meet him.

movie: Manolo: The Boy Who Made Shoes for Lizards
review: A new documentary about the famed designer could use more of the shoes for which he's renowned.
Jennifer Lawrence and Javier Bardem portray a couple in Darren Aronofsky's film, a religious allegory with visual wit and dexterous camera work.
Years after “The Catcher in the Rye” came out, Hollywood was still salivating over it. This film takes a step back to examine the author.
The Ballets Russes de Monte Carlo meld technique with comedy, and tour more than two-thirds of the years
The documentary looks at William Ford Jr., an unarmed black man who was killed by a white man who was never charged.
Sick residents, environmental pollution and questions of corporate accountability in a small town in Arkansas.
Reese Witherspoon plays cute and single in a mirthless romantic comedy in a movie by Hallie Meyers-Shyer, the daughter of Nancy Meyers and Charles Shyer.
This new, updated adaptation follows a bunch of kids on the trail of an evil force.
An Argentine actor, played by Guillermo Pfening, pins his hopes on a movie career in America.
A documentary captures the routines of an Irish boarding school and two of its cherished teachers.
A documentary about Monticchiello in Italy, where each year the residents put on a play about their most urgent concerns.
A promising young priest finds life outside of service, to the detriment of his profession.
Bill Nighy pursues a serial killer in 19th-century London in Juan Carlos Medina's film.
This thoughtful documentary raises tough questions about big-game hunting and wildlife conservation.
A crisis in her marriage sends a woman, played by Karen Allen, to Cape Cod to reflect.
In this romantic comedy, a man can't handle his best friend's revelation that he's gay, throwing their circle of friends and family into disarray.
Three married couples outwit a documentary filmmaker in Lake Bell's sex comedy.
The actions of troubled teenage boys have dire consequences in this Chilean drama.
Murdered women arouse adolescent hormones in this gorgeous Brazilian thriller.
The Czech director Jan Hrebejk's new film shows that a culture of collaboration requires active participation, even if subconscious.
Alicia Vikander, Dane DeHaan and Christoph Waltz star in this much-delayed film about an overripe love triangle in 17th-century Amsterdam.
Noomi Rapace plays an undercover C.I.A. agent in a film that serves up clichés with its suspense.
This film is a handsome, fleet look at the months leading up to the end of British colonial rule in India.
Eliza Hittman's refreshing sophomore feature centers on its main character's existential crisis.
The film focuses on an early chapter in the martial-arts superstar's life, when he battled a Shaolin monk in the Bay Area.
Forget high rents and artisanal pizza. This dystopian glimpse of a Brooklyn neighborhood features an army of snipers and storm troopers.
Adam Wingard has adapted this sprawling Japanese manga series about a high schooler whose world is upended by an ancient notebook.
In case you were uncertain, Mark Gill's unrelentingly dour biopic confirms that the Smiths' singer was a miserable lad.
This risk-averse animated movie features the voices of Elle Fanning, Carly Rae Jepsen and Mel Brooks.
A traumatized car-crash survivor turns into an amateur sleuth, using a machine that records and recovers memories.
The movie sluggishly charts how the ceremonial king acquired real negotiating power during a crisis.
A young doctor struggles with her conscience in this latest film from the Dardenne brothers.
A South Korean action drama deftly gives viewers a first-person view of violence, but falters when trying to convey its emotional costs.
Toa Fraser's film about a hostage crisis at the Iranian Embassy in London in 1980 can feel closer to a re-enactment than a thriller.
This documentary directed by Doug Nichol plumbs the depths of devotion to a machine whose day might appear to be over.
Based on a true story, Matt Ruskin's film stars Lakeith Stanfield as a man who spent decades in prison for a crime he did not commit.
Janicza Bravo's feature debut centers on a would-be actor who is a failure in every respect.
This class-conscious caper, with Channing Tatum and Adam Driver as down-on-their-luck brothers, is ridiculously entertaining.
This showbiz tale finds new talent in Danielle Macdonald, its star, and Geremy Jasper, its writer and director.
“Sidemen: Long Road to Glory” is a loving tribute to the bluesmen Willie Smith, Hubert Sumlin and Joe Willie Perkins.
Mr. Jackson is an ill-tempered contract killer. Ryan Reynolds is his uptight protector. You can figure out the rest.
Fernando Trueba's light ensemble comedy is a romp that pillories Hollywood's deal-making with the Franco regime in the 1950s.
Jang Hun's drama recalls the efforts of the German TV journalist Jürgen Hinzpeter and a cabby he hired to record the Gwangju uprising in 1980.
A couple break up, but remain together, frustratingly, because of the husband's financial woes.
The director David F. Sandberg proves to be a master of the flash-scare as he strings together jolts in this prequel to the 2014 film “Annabelle.”
Robert Pattinson plays a not-too-bright bank robber on the run in Josh and Benny Safdie's latest film, “Good Time.”
Matt Spicer's debut feature is a showcase for Aubrey Plaza's comedic timing and some unbecoming online behavior.
Bertrand Bonello's “Nocturama” chronicles a dramatic attack in Paris, with remarkably little resonance with current events.
The story, set in 1209, finds a group of monks safeguarding a holy relic as they transport it across a violent countryside.
A spiritualist sister act from the United States enchants a film producer in Paris in Rebecca Zlotowski's ambitious feature.
Emer Reynolds's dazzling film traces the history of Voyager 1 and Voyager 2. Like the NASA team that produced these spacecraft, it inspires awe.
Adapted from Jeannette Walls's best-selling memoir of her chaotic childhood, a movie decides to play it safe.
A profiteering mayor threatens to displace a city park's animal residents unless a grumpy squirrel named Surly can wreck his plans.

movie: The Only Living Boy in New York
review: Marc Webb's movie has an all-star cast (Jeff Bridges, Cynthia Nixon, Pierce Brosnan). Yet it lacks a proper story for them.
Steve Coogan and Rob Brydon return for the latest installment in their banter-filled franchise, this time amid the glorious Iberian scenery.
The documentary “Whose Streets?” examines the protests that came after the traumatic police shooting of Michael Brown in 2014.
In a director's feature debut, an impulsive wanderer flees Paris for adventures in rural France.
This absurdly morbid comedy doesn't take itself too seriously, and hopes viewers won't, either, as bodies pile up and the violence never tones down.

movie: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth to Power
review: A follow-up to “An Inconvenient Truth,” with new information on climate change and even some positive developments.
This action-horror hybrid by John Stockwell flirts with intriguing ideas but betrays them with flat characters and undercooked pyrotechnics.
Jody Lambert's lighthearted comedy about the panic in a fictitious town after “The War of the Worlds” radio drama in 1938.
The movie, featuring high-income characters in low-stakes situations, finds a writer returning home to Manhattan to win back a lost love.
The video essayist Kogonada uses architecture to pose larger questions in a small Indiana town.
Kathryn Bigelow's new movie, set amid the Detroit riots of 1967, grapples with the legacy of American racism.
In this comedy, Toni Collette, Molly Shannon, Bridget Everett and Katie Aselton are out to prove that mothers can have fun, too.
“Icarus” was going to be a sort of “Super Size Me” film about steroids but switched gears when Russia was accused of helping Olympic athletes cheat.
This documentary takes you into the mind and body of a young filmmaker, Simon Fitzmaurice, who wakes each morning closer to total paralysis.
This thriller follows a mother in pursuit of the kidnappers who have taken her son. “Wherever you go, I will be right behind you,” she seethes.
Three high school seniors balance applying to college and devoting time to rehearsing for a major dance competition.
Idris Elba and Matthew McConaughey star in “The Dark Tower,” a mess of a movie based on Stephen King's sprawling, multivolume series of the same title.
Two longtime friends, played by Alexandra Daddario and Kate Upton, take a trip to Florida and end up vying for their seatmate's attention.
Lina Rodriguez's film, about a family of three in Colombia, is more consequential than it first appears.
A rookie investigator meets her match while investigating a murder on an Indian reservation.
Charlize Theron plays a spy in “Atomic Blonde,” which comes off like a highlight reel of car crashes and inventively choreographed fights.

movie: From the Land of the Moon
review: Nicole Garcia's turgid adaptation of an Italian novella makes for a silly movie, despite a strong performance from Marion Cotillard.
In the film, a linguist seeks to keep a language alive, but the only two men who speak it aren't interested.
David Singer's film is a modest con movie about the lengths an aspiring actress is willing to go to for some extra cash.
In this sweet, often understated film set in a Hasidic neighborhood, the title character is a widower who must remarry to regain custody of his son.
Dustin Guy Defa wrote and directed this low-budget feature that tells the stories of several New Yorkers over the course of a day.

movie: Rumble: The Indians Who Rocked The World
review: Catherine Bainbridge's “Rumble: The Indians Who Rocked the World” celebrates performers who never fully got their due for their musical contributions.
The documentary filmmaker Fern Levitt wants to shut down the dog-sledding industry. She makes a moving argument.
In this road movie, a woman whose son has committed suicide travels to confront the hot-dog tycoon who stole her son's idea.
In Hollywood, anything goes — even this big-screen tale about those little digital expressions of emotions.
Jessica Williams shines as a young playwright struggling with rejection — professionally and romantically — in this film streaming on Netflix.
This documentary examines why the Dalai Lama is being careful to protect his lineage from Chinese interference.
In war-torn Liberia, Charlize Theron and Javier Bardem face a big problem: how to keep their knotty relationship from fizzling.

movie: Water and Sugar: Carlo Di Palma, the Colours of Life
review: This documentary celebrates the Italian cinematographer who brought a golden touch to his collaborations with Michelangelo Antonioni and Woody Allen.
In Ingrid Jungermann's droll comedy, ex-lovers who produce a podcast about serial killers find themselves at odds when a new romantic interest emerges.
In his brilliant new film, Christopher Nolan revisits a harrowing, true World War II mission in a story of struggle, survival and resistance.
A deep-woods thriller stars Bruce Willis as the local police chief and features a bank robbery gone wrong.
In the affably amusing, sometimes spittingly funny “Girls Trip,” a weekend getaway brings trouble, laughs and sisterhood.
This Argentine film, very loosely inspired by the Bartok opera “Bluebeard's Castle,” observes the lives of teenage girls on the verge of adulthood.
The movie, set in an Australian national park, features two families and one set of brutal killers.
Jenny Slate, John Turturro and Edie Falco star in Gillian Robespierre's new comedy, set in 1995.
The Italian directors Tizza Covi and Rainer Frimmel's hybrid of a film follows a young man on a sort of odyssey across Italy.
A documentary finds a group of young people in violence-plagued Richmond, Calif., staging their own version of Romeo and Juliet's romantic tragedy.
A Dutch couple goes off the grid to live a quiet life in Spain, but their idyll ends in a true crime mystery that is the subject of this documentary.
Kavi Raz's film, based on the true story of Duleep Singh, never finds a rhythm or dramatic arc.
In 1950s Estonia, a principal's envy of a popular teacher leads him to start investigating his background.
Two great French actresses, Catherine Deneuve and Catherine Frot, share the screen in this film about forgiveness and redemption.
A film about a prize for excellence in journalism and the arts shares some winners' insights, but not enough.
A slimy, many-tentacled alien has sex with several unhappy residents of the Mexican city of Guanajuato in Amat Escalante's movie.
If you can summarize the plot of Luc Besson's film adaptation of the graphic-novel science fiction series, you weren't paying attention.
The documentary argues that not just pregnancy-related treatment, but also all manner of health care for women, is under constant attack.
Alec Baldwin and Demi Moore star in a clumsy tale about a cranky blind writer and a married woman who finds him affair-worthy.
A documentary revisits a harrowing solo performance piece that explores the sexual awakening of two girls in the Bronx.
Jeff Orlowski's documentary emphasizes that climate change isn't just an aboveground phenomenon — warmer oceans mean that coral reefs are in peril, too.
An 88-year-old polymath's nostalgic look back on the Chilean literary scene in the late 1940s.
A Marxist musical comedy follows its heroine into a luxury shoe factory and then into a labor dispute.
Victim or villain, flower or serpent? In this British movie, a young 19th-century woman finds passion, makes mischief and commits murder.
Kumail Nanjiani stars opposite Zoe Kazan in this very funny, moving true story about how he found and almost lost love. Holly Hunter and Ray Romano also star.
A documentary initially focused on Thailand's sex industry takes a sharp turn when the filmmakers begin to doubt the activist who is their guide.

movie: War for the Planet of the Apes
review: With Andy Serkis reprising his role as Caesar, “War for the Planet of the Apes” is a humane western wrapped around a prison movie, as primates battle for primacy.
A teenager unhappy with her circumstances falls prey to a strange box, and it doesn't bode well for the resident high school meanie.
Casey Affleck and Rooney Mara play a young couple, one of whom is dead, in David Lowery's haunting new film.
Dumb-comedy season is here: Linda Cardellini stars as a manipulative mother who turns to kidnapping when her pageant dreams for her daughter fizzle.
In this documentary, Matthew Heineman (“Cartel Land”) focuses on the gutsy Syrian citizen-journalist group called Raqqa Is Being Slaughtered Silently.
This superhero is back in a reboot that features new faces and familiar fights. Tom Holland wears the suit, but Michael Keaton owns the movie.
Lara Stolman's documentary follows a Special Olympics team for autistic kids, the Jersey Hammerheads, and the challenges they face.
A German biopic tells the story of Georg Elser, a carpenter who tried to blow up the Führer in 1939.
Burning rubber and hot licks help propel this action movie about a getaway driver named Baby, played by Ansel Elgort. Edgar Wright directed.
A woman returns to the site of a family murder only to find the evil spirit that caused it is still hanging around.
Steve Carell and Kristen Wiig revisit their familiar characters, but the goings-on show signs of wear even as the energy level escalates.
Elsa Dorfman, a subject of seemingly modest import for a documentary, emerges here as an artist of deep compassion, empathy, humor and wisdom.
This biopic, starring Karolina Gruszka, highlights about six years in the life of the Nobel Prize-winning scientist.
Bong Joon-ho's latest film on Netflix is a high-speed satire with a conscience and a heart. And Tilda Swinton in braces.
This film, produced by Jackie Chan, is a tense sci-fi action thriller with a strong female lead.
The job didn't work out in the end, but this riveting film documents a choreographer's cheerfully tenacious effort as well as his work on one ballet.
Ms. Coppola won best director at the Cannes Film Festival for her film starring Nicole Kidman and Colin Farrell, an update on the 1971 movie with Clint Eastwood.
Will Ferrell and Amy Poehler play a couple who embark on a nefarious scheme in which the odds are always in their favor.
The film borrows from Boccaccio, with a sprinkling of Monty Python, for this irreverent comedy set in an Italian convent.
A documentary assembled from archival video offers a glimpse of the 40th president's character, but focuses mostly on relations with the Soviets.
A documentary by Jamie Kastner is about a fugitive convicted in the deaths of eight people at a golf course in the Virgin Islands.
This documentary looks at Dr. John Sarno, who posits that many types of chronic pain, particularly back pain, are caused by stress and repressed emotions.

movie: Can't Stop, Won't Stop: A Bad Boy Story
review: Daniel Kaufman's documentary covers a lot of Mr. Combs's history as it records preparations for Bad Boy reunion concerts in Brooklyn.
Scott Hamilton Kennedy's documentary gives G.M.O. opponents their say, but leaves the last word to food technologists, who insist on reviewing the data.
Patrick Shen's documentary explores the harmful effects of excessive sound, linking quietude to tranquillity and better health.
Albert Maysles's last documentary observes passengers traveling Amtrak's route between Chicago and the Pacific Northwest.

movie: Nobody Speak: Trials of the Free Press
review: Brian Knappenberger's timely documentary serves as an impassioned defense of the news media, though it lacks depth.
A documentary observes the rising tide of danger and displacement for families living in central Iraq amid the arrival of the Islamic State.
The film, with a powerhouse performance by Dolores Fonzi, follows a young Argentine woman who confronts a horrible event in a rural town.
An updated tale of ostracism for the golden age of dystopia, written and directed by Ana Lily Amirpour.
Mark Wahlberg is back in the latest “Transformers” movie, but it's stolen by Anthony Hopkins and a grouchy C-3PO knockoff.
Mandy Moore and Claire Holt play sisters looking for adventures in Mexico, but being stuck in a cage on the ocean floor wasn't what they had in mind.
Benny Boom's film fails the considerable talent of the complex rapper it chronicles and the actor portraying him, Demetrius Shipp Jr.
Lightning is back and feeling a bit old in this latest breezy feature in the Pixar franchise. It offers life lessons that will resonate with adults as well as with children.
A mysterious man becomes a disruptive presence for a married couple and their daughter in Koji Fukada's well-acted family drama.
Dan Stevens contends with drones, militants and a video-game-style parallel universe in his quest to save humanity in this sci-fi feature.

movie: Once Upon a Time in Venice
review: A private detective is desperate to recover his stolen dog in this action-comedy from Mark and Robb Cullen.
Scarlett Johansson and Kate McKinnon play old friends whose boozy bachelorette weekend goes very, very wrong in a comedy from Lucia Aniello.
Naomi Watts stars in a cliché-stuffed dumb movie about a smart kid, directed by Colin Trevorrow (“Jurassic World”).
Nick Hamm's drama imagines a fictional drive shared by the Irish republican leader Martin McGuinness and the Unionist Ian Paisley.
Ari Issler and Ben Snyder's intimate feature focuses on a young soldier who comes back from Afghanistan to face the fallout from a long-ago crime.
Fiona Tan's ode to this volcanic mountain draws on a scripted voice-over to impart observations and histories.
Zoe Lister-Jones wrote, directed and stars in this comedy about an out-of-sync couple turning their squabbles into songs.
Class polarization makes for an uncomfortable dinner party in this film written by Mike White and directed by Miguel Arteta.
This horror movie, the feature debut of the writer-director Aaron B. Koontz, has good actors but too many motifs derived from other fright films.
The sophomore feature by Trey Edward Shults is as spookily self-assured and ambitious as “Krisha.”
Based on a true story, this film, starring Kate Mara, is both harrowing and heartstring-tugging.
A boy in pursuit of a college sports scholarship crosses a boundary in a real-life story starring Tim Boardman and Molly Shannon.
The interlocking stories in this feature show off a bright metropolis filled with familial dysfunction and frustrated love affairs.
Brett Haley's low-key feature, about an older actor seeking redemption after being reduced to a cliché, belongs to its star, Sam Elliott.
This reboot of a monster franchise could have been creepy or campy, but it settles for the dreary action-blockbuster template.

movie: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie
review: DreamWorks brings the book series to the screen, riding the voices of Kevin Hart and Thomas Middleditch and a story featuring huge bathroom fixtures.
This film re-examines Winston Churchill's image as a gruff British bulldog of a leader by shining a light on his struggle with depression.
The comic tries his hand at writing and directing a feature film, producing a sweet, humorous drama about loss.
Two unlikely friends at an all-boys school in Ireland must survive their classmates' bullying with the help of a sympathetic teacher.
A documentary about the British explorer Gertrude Bell focuses on her role in drawing the modern borders of Iraq.
This film by the Israeli director Avi Nesher, based on Baruch Milch's memoir, uses a potboiler setup to delve into themes of history and reconciliation.
This historical action movie from Yoshinari Nishikori has a laudably realistic grit and takes an unexpected turn for a film of its genre.
Christopher Plummer plays the exiled German Kaiser Wilhelm II in this melodrama, which unfolds in the Netherlands in the early years of the Second World War.
Otis Mass's documentary portrait of a Manhattan celebrity photographer reflects a talented but exasperating pro.

movie: Turn It Around: The Story of East Bay Punk
review: A sprawling documentary retraces the birth of the punk scene in the Bay Area, where bands like Green Day and Rancid came together and thrived.
This combination crime drama and romance finds Emile Hirsch and Zoë Kravitz circling each other, and trying to stay away from bad guys.
The movie, directed by Patty Jenkins and starring Gal Gadot, shakes off branding imperatives with touches of screwball comedy and romantic adventure.
Dwayne Johnson and his lifeguard squad try to save the Bay while providing the sort of sleazy, wholesome entertainment this '90s series was known for.
Teresa Palmer has a breakthrough role as a young woman on holiday in Berlin whose instant romance with a stranger results in her abduction.
This vital, informative companion piece to Wim Wenders's 1999 documentary chronicles the late-life careers, and deaths, of the “Buena Vista” stars.
Jason Bourque's thriller examines the moral compromises of meting out death from afar, and the unraveling of a home when a victim comes to supper.
Amir Bar-Lev's four-hour documentary chronicles the band's deeply musical journey while placing it at the joyous center of the counterculture.

movie: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales
review: The latest in the “Pirates of the Caribbean” franchise brings back Johnny Depp's Captain Sparrow but leaves the joy an ocean away.
A documentary captures this ballerina at a critical moment in 2013, when she was both trying for a comeback and coming to terms with aging.
The power and resourcefulness of women are on display in this small-scale comedy, which manages to speak to a broader political movement.
Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal is the commander alluded to in David Michôd's satirical portrait of a man in over his head and enthralled by his own hype.
This passionate political movie tells the story of Wladyslaw Strzeminski, a real-life artist who suffered under Soviet rule.
The new entry in Ridley Scott's long-lived franchise is committed to the canny management of expectations, but that doesn't diminish its creepiness.

movie: Diary of a Wimpy Kid: The Long Haul
review: Greg and his brothers are dragged on a dreary road trip by their parents. You can probably guess the rest.
Amandla Stenberg plays a teenager with an immune system disorder who falls for the boy next door, and risks everything.
In this adaptation of Janet Fitch's novel, two women react very differently to a suicide.
A fictional San Francisco radio station provides a place for immigrants adrift to bond in the ether.
Trine Dyrholm is “magnificent” as a woman buckling under the strain of her career and her marriage in Thomas Vinterberg's latest film.
From the modern Philippines, Lav Diaz's haunting and pessimistic take on a Tolstoy story.
A man indulges a fantasy to escape his routine by camping out in a storage room above his garage and observing his own absence.
Alex Karpovsky of “Girls” stars as a bad comic opening for a good folk-rocker. As their trip rolls along, tensions bubble up.
The operative Roger J. Stone Jr. has a scandalous history, a Nixon tattoo and boldfaced acquaintances, including President Trump, all explored in this documentary.

movie: King Arthur: Legend of the Sword
review: The Arthurian legend gets a makeover with quips, winks, body blows, digital elephants and an easy, breezy Charlie Hunnam.
A father is immersed in the lowrider world, while a son wants only to pursue his art. And then another son is released from prison.
Julian Rosefeldt's art installation is now a film, with this chameleonic actress morphing into multiple characters.
In this film, Diane Lane stars as a Hollywood producer's wife whose road trip to Paris becomes a journey of self-discovery — and a gastronomic affair.
Amy Schumer teams up with Goldie Hawn in “Snatched.” Only one of them gets to be funny.
Working with a minimalist script and a tight budget, the director Doug Liman brings vein-popping intensity to a claustrophobic standoff in Iraq.
Rama Burshtein received acclaim for her debut feature, “Fill the Void.” Now she's back with another biting, multilayered romantic comedy.
Alexi Pappas, a runner who, in real life, competed at the 2016 Olympics, helped write, direct and produce — and stars in — a film about a runner.
A social worker tries to connect with a troubled 17-year-old through music, but the girl's street-tough best friend stands in the way.
The islanders are still driven to lawlessness after their whisky runs out, but this remake lacks the luster of the original.

movie: Angkor Awakens: A Portrait of Cambodia
review: Robert H. Lieberman's documentary scrutinizes the harrowing abuses and tormented legacy of the Khmer Rouge regime.
In this ultra-low-budget ghost story, the living may exhibit more unsettling behavior than the dead.
A documentary looks at Chris Burden, who had himself shot, crucified and more, all for the sake of his performance art.
Liev Schreiber may not resemble Chuck Wepner, but he convincingly portrays this boxer, whose 1975 bout with Muhammad Ali inspired Sylvester Stallone.
Chris Pratt, Zoe Saldana and the crew are back for this sequel to the 2014 hit about a ragtag group of futuristic fighters.
Though this documentary looks at the artist and his work, it is more concerned with layering on the admiration.
In this documentary by Jill Campbell, the former N.B.A. point guard hopes to develop a life after the clock runs out on his athletic career.
This Laura Poitras documentary follows the elusive and evasive WikiLeaks founder over several years, but real-time events have overtaken the film's tale.
This documentary, using footage shot by 40 filmmakers in 25 countries, depicts the uses and rituals of religion in a range of environments.
Wang Bing's documentary observes refugees from the Kokang region in Myanmar who have fled across the border into China.
This deadpan comedy starring Taylor Schilling and Pat Healy features a fake abduction that gets all too real.
Richard Gere and Steve Coogan face off as estranged brothers with serious family matters to attend to in this film adaptation of Herman Koch's book.
Debra Winger and Tracy Letts play a couple whose passions for each other have reignited, to the chagrin of their lovers.
This intense debut feature from the Irish director Liam Gavin, with its spare style, is a marriage of acting and atmosphere.
Mr. Malek, of “Mr. Robot,” heads for the hills of Montana as a man fleeing a soul-deadening job and the burdens of modern life.
In a conceptual exercise, actors audition for roles in the celebrated case as a way of showing how people are still preoccupied by it.

movie: Harold and Lillian: A Hollywood Love Story
review: Meet the husband-and-wife team that inspired some of the most memorable moments onscreen, from “The Graduate” to “The Birds.”

movie: How to Be a Latin Lover
review: In this good-natured comedy, the Mexican actor and comedian has been dumped and has to settle for real life.
This documentary, one of several commemorating the riots' 25th anniversary, assembles broadcast and helicopter footage into a taut chronological account.
Politicians, the police, victims and survivors deliver an oral history of the rising racial tensions that led to the early-1990s Los Angeles riots.
When a morose Russian teenager comes to town, a 16-year-old in the Toronto suburbs meets his match.
A drama from Brazil about a psychiatrist who defied medical orthodoxy and treated patients with paint brushes instead of spikes and electroshock therapy.
Noomi Rapace plays a woman subjected to jumbo syringes and repulsive nuzzling after being kidnapped by a mysterious cult.
Emma Watson and Tom Hanks star in this adaptation of a Dave Eggers novel that explores surveillance-state threats.
Disneynature's latest documentary visits remote parts of China to provide rare glimpses of young animals in the wild.

movie: Citizen Jane: Battle for the City
review: Jane Jacobs fought against Robert Moses' plans to develop Lower Manhattan. This documentary revisits their legendary feud.
Ben Wheatley's formula for action-movie success: a best actress Oscar winner, dozens of firearms and a warehouse full of testosterone.
Lydia Tenaglia's documentary is a portrait of Mr. Tower, a force behind the California Cuisine movement in the 1970s, among other culinary feats.
This documentary follows biologists to Antarctica, where they estimate the animals' numbers and gauge the damage of climate change.
Oscar Isaac, Christian Bale and Charlotte Le Bon star in this wartime romance with a heavy subject (genocide) but a corny plot.
Rosario Dawson and Katherine Heigl star in a thriller that works a wearyingly familiar formula.

movie: Chasing Trane: The John Coltrane Documentary
review: John Scheinfeld's documentary about John Coltrane draws on interviews, including those with Bill Clinton, Carlos Santana and Cornel West.
This documentary looks at a Guatemalan village that was wiped out during a civil war, and searches for one of the few survivors.
A family ventures beyond the bubble of gentrified Brooklyn to a small town and is thrown out of its comfort zone.
‘Norman: The Moderate Rise and Tragic Fall of a New York Fixer,' Joseph Cedar's latest film, pits Jew against Jew on the fringes of power and influence.
Each installment of “Fast and Furious” is more enjoyably ludicrous than the last, even as the death of the star Paul Walker continues to hang over the franchise.
Charlie Hunnam stars in this period adventure story about love, loss and mystery in the Amazon from the director James Gray.
The director Jason Connery's staid biopic is about the 19th-century golf pioneer Tom Morris and his son, with class conflict as a backdrop.
The fast-faced documentary “Tomorrow” profiles men and women with concrete solutions for moving away from fossil fuels and protecting the environment.
A Polish film follows its young protagonist as he flirts, attends parties until dawn and gyrates to a perpetual backbeat.
A young math prodigy and her strong bond with her uncle are tested when a debate arises over whether to cultivate her abilities or let her be a child.
Michael Caine, Alan Arkin and Morgan Freeman star in a comedy about old dudes who rob a bank, a remake of a 1979 movie.
Stephen Karam's film adaptation of his own play is a comedy about students who don't quite fit in but insist, in their clumsy way, on being heard.
In Walter Hill's film, a revenge plot is set in motion after a hit man, played by Michelle Rodriguez, undergoes a forced gender reassignment surgery.
In this drama, Dan Stevens is exceptional as a blind man who is less than happy with what he sees after his sight is restored.
Gemma Arterton stars in this World War II drama about a screenwriter who's hired to create uplift and propaganda. From the director of “An Education.”
Manohla Dargis reviews Makoto Shinkai's latest film, a lovely and touching Japanese animation in which teenagers find themselves trading bodies and lives.
This limber, light-footed documentary becomes a sort of dreamy film diary for the girls it profiles.
A new film offers an intimate, searching portrait of the turbulent friendship between the writer and the painter.
A screen adaptation of Mark Harris's 2014 book adds visuals to the story of five Hollywood directors who served in World War II with cameras in tow.
Scarlett Johansson, playing a cyborg called Major, rises above it all in the thrill-free science fiction thriller.
These documentaries go behind the scenes with their well-known subjects, Rose Marie and Gilbert Gottfried.
In this documentary, a filmmaker returns to her hometown in the former East Germany seeking personal and political insight.
This first feature by the director Logan Sandler has great acting, stunning imagery and a vivid Caribbean setting. But its words prove elusive.
The sequel to the gloriously scabrous film that kick-started the careers of Danny Boyle and Ewan McGregor illustrates the consequences of a misspent youth.
An animated feature starring a newborn with an oh-so-familiar voice may confuse the kiddies, but grown-ups should get a kick out of it.
This true story of a couple who sheltered Jews beneath the Warsaw Zoo has tender moments but its portrayal of the Nazi invasion is too timid and sanitized.
A story of obsession plays out in “Wilde Salomé” and “Salomé,” as Mr. Pacino veers into Camp.
In Elisabeth Subrin's feature, a nuanced take on friendship and professional frustration, an actress finds that early relationships can fade.
The documentary traces the experiences of six women who settled in the United States after the end of World War II.
This unrepentantly lewd comedy, based on the 1977-83 television series of the same name, stars Dax Shepard, who also wrote and directed.
Hunter Adams shows his skill as a filmmaker, delivering a chiller that conjures eeriness and dread without defaulting to abundant gore.
The director Kasper Collin has created a suave and sensitive documentary about the life and death of the great trumpeter Lee Morgan.
This Czech film gives a haunting account of the life of the mentally ill young woman who killed eight people in Prague in 1973.
This movie offers proof of life on another planet, sure, but it is also the occasion for another “Alien”-type deadly game of hide-and-seek.
Anshai Lal's Bollywood movie uses a friendly ghost to turn a contemporary comedy into a historical drama that includes a massacre under British rule.
The popular 1990s series receives a big-screen reboot, and five new teenage superheroes face off against the latest alien threat.
Alice Lowe wrote, directed and stars in this British film about a pregnant serial killer on a darkly comedic odyssey dictated by her malicious fetus.
A movie, based on Daniel Clowes's graphic novel, about a man's well-requited contempt for humanity.
The Japanese director Hirokazu Kore-eda's latest family drama, focusing on a writer who's fallen on hard times, works in a quiet cinematic register.
This sci-fi thriller may not have “Arrival”-level effects or sophistication, but it delivers a solid B-movie kick.
A compassionate Belle and a splendid monster are the hallmarks of this live-action remake of the 1991 animated film.
A documentary looks at a hedge fund manager's $1 billion bet against that nutritional company and his efforts to expose what he characterized as consumer fraud.
Nathan Morlando's film may focus on two young lovers, but Bill Paxton shines as a corrupt sheriff in one of his final film roles.
This drama about intersecting love lives features themes like betrayal, identity and art. Religion appears, too, in the film, set in Austin, Tex.
This film, set in Colombia, wallows in the cheap and hackneyed irony of choreographed slaughter.
Acting may be his first love, but the title character in “Actor Martinez” soon learns it's no picnic — especially when dealing with his directors.
This Bollywood rom-com, directed by Shashank Khaitan, describes the growing pains of a gentleman whose fiancée teaches him to acknowledge her equality.
In this remake, the beast King Kong has a new look and a new beauty (Brie Larson), who's feistier than her predecessors.
The British journalist Louis Theroux relies on a meandering charm in this documentary examining the Church of Scientology's hold on its members.
Olivier Assayas's new film is both a supernatural thriller and an unnerving inquiry into the drift and mystery of modern life.
Julia Ducournau's film unfolds during rush week in a nightmarish veterinary school.
A nurse travels to the Ottoman Empire on the eve of World War I. Can romance blossom amid earthshaking events?
Adapted from Julian Barnes's 2011 novel, Ritesh Batra's film portrays an emotionally detached man gingerly revisiting his past.
Caveh Zahedi, the film's director and star, recounts the misadventures experienced while producing an initially sexually explicit semidocumentary series.
Featuring Ornette Coleman and Marianne Faithfull, the music provides counterpoint to a tale of patients from a psychiatric institution on a kind of holiday.
In this film from Singapore, the chief executioner at a high-security prison takes on a new assistant.
Zoey Deutch relives a day repeatedly until she gets it right in this film based on a young-adult novel.
Issues of sovereignty in the Middle East are revisited in a pair of documentaries.
A documentary follows bottle and can collectors in New York as they toil to fill their carts for $30 or $40 a day.
There are echoes of “Paris Is Burning” in this documentary, which chronicles a tight-knit community in New York. Yet there is a striking absence of elder mentors.
This is old-school meets new-school pulp filled with intimations of mortality, and raw, ugly violence. And once again, Hugh Jackman plays the Wolverine.
Kelly Daniela Norris and T. W. Pittman's movie tells the story of a young medical student in Ghana, who returns home to a village to pay off a debt.
Slapstick and sap vie for prominence in a comedy so lazy that it actually features someone falling off a log.
The 82-year-old actress holds your attention, but this film about a woman padding out her future obituary has an artificial ring.
Sam Worthington and Octavia Spencer star in “The Shack,” a Christian-themed film based on a best seller.
Taylor John Smith and Michael Shannon star in a sports film that transcends its stock characters for a while but eventually disappoints.
Two teenage boys in the 1990s bond over alt-rock only to have their friendship strained in this first feature directed by Miles Joris-Peyrafitte.
Prettily filmed yet parochial, this film follows two lovers through a mass starvation in the early 1930s.
Paul Toogood and Lloyd Stanton's documentary talks to comedians about the rigors of the road and other stresses of their profession.
This movie by Jordan Peele, his first as a director of feature films, is a skillful hybrid, blending genres into something terrifying.
This animated tale of an orphan, freighted with the name Icare, or Icarus, is more charming than grim.
This documentary reflects on a legacy of political turmoil as the director, Dominique Dubosc, returns to Paraguay after 40 years.
An animated movie for children is elevated by a fine vocal performance from Eddie Izzard.
This thriller from Gore Verbinski makes for a nice game of Name That Movie Influence as it treads the boundary between homage and outright plagiarism.
Anne Hamilton's film seems full of suspenseful promise as it opens on an isolated swath of the country's heartland, but the story finds no traction.

movie: Breaking Point: The War for Democracy in Ukraine
review: The documentary, directed by Mark Jonathan Harris and Oles Sanin, looks at Russian aggression toward the country, which is struggling to rebuild.
A messed-up heroine is asked to choose between naughty and nice in Catalina Aguilar Mastretta's sophomore feature, which is predictable but satisfying.
It's the last day of school, and two teachers are getting ready to rumble in this comedy directed by Richie Keen.
Julianne Nicholson plays a Bronx high school teacher who tries to help three undocumented students cope with the threat of being discovered by the authorities.
Written and directed by Kazik Radwanski, this film was shot in practically all hand-held almost close-ups.
The movie, directed by So Yong Kim, explores the mystery of unspoken love.
Evanna Lynch, of “Harry Potter,” plays a teenager who leaves her foster home to search for her institutionalized father.
Zhang Yimou's costume spectacle offers drooling creatures, glowering warriors, a swaggering mercenary and a message about China's might.
This debut feature by Minhal Baig has two high school students, a couple in their 30s and a dash of charm.
This romance illustrates the struggle for African independence from colonialism, under the shadow of apartheid.
This formulaic horror movie features teenagers behaving badly and suffering the consequences.
Colin Hanks's documentary follows the band that was playing at the Bataclan in Paris when terrorists struck in 2015.
Will moviegoers want to surrender control to this sequel to “Fifty Shades of Grey”?
This documentary is a chronicle of the fight to hold an online classifieds site liable for children being sold into sex slavery.
This sequel is an altogether more solemn affair than the original, weighed down by the philosophy that more is always more.
This documentary profiles distinctive street cats in Istanbul and the human communities that interact with them.
This documents how the career of the far-right Hungarian politician Csanad Szegedi was upended when he found out about his lineage.
This documentary focuses on Mayer Vishner, a man who has decided to end his life, and finds the filmmaker in an uncomfortable position.
This second feature by the Thai director Pimpaka Towira finds three young adults on an enigmatic journey.
Warner Bros. offers amusement at its own expense and Will Arnett gives great voice to Gotham's brooder, but this new movie is still a commercial.
Friedrich Moser's documentary employs re-enactments, moving graphics and a Philip Glass-like score.
Robert Legato's horror movie is “a strange mix of the recycled and the surreal,” Jeannette Catsoulis writes.
This gentle coming-of-age film centers on a youngster caught between two cultures and struggling to adapt in suburbia.
Raoul Peck's documentary is an important introduction to James Baldwin's work and an advanced seminar in racial politics.
Teenagers on the run, with a motorcycle, and hints of the 1960s.
Tomer Heymann's documentary on the Israeli choreographer Ohad Naharin is a scattered and somewhat confused film about an intriguing and complicated man.
The latest in a horror franchise that began in Japan, this film fills in the back story of Samara, the girl who kills via VCR.
Joined by a cast that includes Edie Falco and Harvey Keitel, Mr. De Niro plays an insult comic in a film that, like its jokes, lacks zing.
Peter Chelsom's movie concerns a young human (Asa Butterfield), raised in isolation on Mars, who visits Earth and a video-chat pal (Britt Robertson).
Barbara Kopple's film documents how Gigi Gorgeous, formerly Gregory Allan Lazzarato, took control of her transgender destiny with the support of her family.
This film, opening amid a call for a PETA boycott, is a string of hero-dog fantasies and observations from the canine point of view.
He plays a rogue who strikes it rich, a thrill complicated by the corruptions of wealth, treachery and the schemer's own fecklessness.
Mr. Chan mugs and thwarts assailants in this harmless international romp.
Evan Oppenheimer's film is a mild romantic drama with a guy perspective, featuring beautiful women and a brutal athletic spectacle.
This documentary explores the value of a Shakespeare production intended to help residents heal after the horrific school shooting.
The “king of Bollywood” rarely plays the bad guy, but in this film he's a criminal who's also fighting corruption in 1980s and '90s India.
In the sixth entry in Paul W. S. Anderson's dystopian franchise, Milla Jovovich's character is back in zombie land, aided by her former nemesis the Red Queen.
This documentary centers on the challenges faced by five young women who make up the first female streetcar racing team in the Middle East.
Jared P. Scott's film explores the issue from the perspective of military experts rather than that of scientists. The information is compelling, but the movie is ham-handed.
This drama, set in a declining Australian logging town, centers on an estranged son who comes home, smoldering with resentment.
The difficult family life of the Polish painter Zdzislaw Beksinski makes for an often funny but also harrowing and heartbreaking film.
The ghost of Willy Loman hovers over this film from Asghar Farhadi, but it seems occupied with its own dramatic issues, our critic writes.
Annette Bening stars as a complicated and divorced Santa Barbara mother in Mike Mills's funny, emotionally piercing new film.
“Split” represents something of a return to form — or formula — for its writer and director, M. Night Shyamalan. It's all plot, spun into a ribbon of suspense.
In Alain Guiraudie's quirky hybrid of thriller, sex comedy and folk tale, a screenwriter meets a shepherdess and, voilà, a baby is born.
Mr. Keaton's kinetic performance as the man who made McDonald's what it is today doesn't enhance the movie; it is the movie.
This largely nonverbal animated French-Belgian-Japanese coproduction, from Studio Ghibli, the home of Hayao Miyazaki, flirts with eco-mysticism.
This debut feature by the Mexican writer and director Emiliano Rocha Minter seems to build on the character of Coffin Joe in the 1960s films by José Mojica Marins.
In the third installment of this franchise, the hero and new oddball allies set out to retrieve a stolen superweapon.
Idris Elba is among the stars of this Jim O'Hanlon film, a converging-narratives movie set in London.
Prep-school students in Saturday detention are trapped on campus to die one by one in this film directed by Ben Browder, a sequel to “Bad Kids Go to Hell.”
In this film, the latest written and directed by Lisa Robinson and Annie J. Howell, a wife searches for clues and finds larger unanswered questions.
Ben Affleck directed and stars in this gangster movie set in the 1920s, in which he tries to pour new wine into a bullet-riddled vessel.
A small-town teenager and a creature released by a geyser are unlikely friends in this live-action eco-fable from the “Ice Age” director Chris Wedge.
This entry in the “One Piece” anime franchise involves the liberation of gamblers on a floating casino complex.
This film declines to consider the jihadist ideology that apparently motivated the Boston Marathon bombers.
This documentary honors the street-based work of the British artist known as Banksy, and implicitly criticizes those who would try to turn profits from it.
This entry in the dad-to-the-rescue action-movie genre doesn't have enough twists to even tie a shoelace.
This movie melds the summon-the-evil-by-its-name convention with the old try-not-to-think-of-an-elephant mind game, with scary results.
Eugène Green's new movie is divided into five sections, each titled after a biblical episode.
Cosmo Feilding Mellen's documentary suggests that two young men saw themselves as spreading transcendence one hit at a time.
Liam Neeson is the voice of a giant tree that helps a child with a vivid imagination through difficult times.
This movie, directed by Steven C. Miller, follows two brothers under pressure by a crime boss in Mississippi.
The women, part of the giant step for mankind, have their stories told in this movie directed by Theodore Melfi.
The bloat of this routine South Korean crime thriller, directed by Cho Ui-seok, magnifies its generic qualities.
Mr. Chan, 62, dazzles in this action movie set during the Second Sino-Japanese War, but the most challenging moves are left to younger stuntmen.
In Martin Scorsese's film, Jesuit priests in 17th-century Japan operate underground to keep their religion alive when they and their adherents are persecuted.
Robin Pront's film depicts a man who took the fall for a crime and who catches up with his brother and his girlfriend, now reformed and in a relationship, four years later.
This action-horror franchise about warring vampires and werewolves returns for a fifth outing. But is it a sequel or a dissertation?
